Derwent secure Cup progression with win over James

07/06/2013

Derwent firsts secured their progression through to the Cup with a stylish 3-0 win over James seconds on the JLD this afternoon

Image by

By undefined undefined

DERWENT FIRSTS 3-0 JAMES SECONDS Group D
Images: Lily Grant Derwent firsts secured their progression through to the Cup with a stylish 3-0 win over James seconds on the JLD this afternoon. Goals from Sam Earle, Dan Atherton and David Kirk gave Derwent the edge over their opposition in what was a must win game for James in order to keep their Cup hopes alive. The game started with Derwent pouring men forward in an effort to break down James' back four, but Derwent were unable to convert their pressure into a goal and James responded in similar fashion. Both sides failed to create any clear chances as the first ten minutes trickled past. Kirushanthan Sivagnanam showed off his pace early on for James, his good cross into the box ended up being fired straight at the keeper though, with no one able to get on the end of it. Derwent had a penalty shout midway through the first half with Will Manners appearing to take Jamie Trant down in the area without making any contact with the ball. The referee waved play on however, much to the dismay of the Derwent players. One of the best chances of the first half came not long after when Dan Atherton, who had a brilliant game, struck the post with a fantastic strike full of pace and strength. Andy Lake failed to gather the ball and Trant scuffed his rebound attempt and James had some breathing space. A Derwent corner very nearly saw them take the lead, but Ollie Harrison's deflection was hacked off the line by the James defence in a vital stop. Atherton then went on a lovely run down the middle of the pitch and had a go from distance, Andy Lake produced a very decent save though to deny Derwent the lead before half time. Half time saw the game still at 0-0, with both sides still searching for that elusive first goal. Trant almost made the breakthrough immediately after the restart but he smashed the ball into the side netting. He was subbed off soon after for Ryan Gwinnett as Derwent tried to breathe life into the match with fresh legs. Atherton had yet another chance when he hooked a shot straight at Lake, who couldn't gather the ball cleanly and spilled it into the path of David Kirk who seized onto the rebound shot, but in a miraculous double save Lake was able to stop the ball with his legs. Tom Brandreth almost scored an amazing goal for Derwent when he tried a shot from a few yards inside the half way line, but somehow the ball struck the crossbar to the agony of the Derwent fans. The goal finally came through Sam Earle who scored an absolute screamer from 25 yards, he turned and directed the ball into the net with a beauty of a strike to give Derwent a 1-0 lead. It was all Derwent after that, Ryan Gwinnett attempted to chip the ball over the keeper when he was one on one but the ball sailed just over the bar. James were to concede an unfortunate goal next, David Kirk crossed the ball to Dan Atheron who flicked the ball into the back of the net but the James players were incensed as Kirk looked to be a few yards offside when he made the cross. It was Kirk who sealed the match for Derwent, he accepted a lovely cross from Gwinnett in front of goal and slotted the ball in from the near post to ensure Derwent finished second in the group and were progressing through to the Cup. A disappointed James captain Matija Pisk spoke candidly after the game, "Obviously we're gutted today, I thought we made a really good game of it. While they were the better team, I thought we defended pretty well, kept the chances down and they rode their luck a little bit. When they scored it was sort of all over though. We're proud of ourselves in a sense because we're in such a difficult group, so we can take a lot of positives. We're through to the Plate and I expect us to win that." Derwent captain Ollie Harrison was clearly delighted with his team, saying, "We're delighted with the performance, it was very difficult in these conditions. We had a lot of players who put in top performances. Looking to the quarter finals now, I think we're in a strong positions. Goodricke, we know what they've got, but we're confident going forward."
